body: @csantanapr Rebased to master & addressed comments.

@bjustin-ibm - no, there's no explicit redirection test - kind of tricky and i guess i'm trusting the request package to handle that setting per it's docs.  all existing tests pass as expected.  there's a separate environment with an api gw hosted in a domain that redirects to another domain - my plan is to manually test this change in that environment to confirm the desired behavior.
@mdeuser, good catch. I made an update that should ensure that existing annotations are overwritten if new annotations with matching keys are provided. Modified the test accordingly.
yeah doing the docs, forgot to push
for all the style related comments, https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/tree/master/tools/eclipse has an eclipse code formatting style. maybe we need automatic style checks now.
@ningyougang fyi - I'am currently reviewing and trying to understand the details of this PR and running a PG. will come back to you soon.
My ICLA has been acknowledged by Apache, is that what you're referring to?

@tysonnorris would you adjust the scala formatting to the rest of the code as defined here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/tree/master/tools/eclipse

@markusthoemmes I'm having trouble applying the eclipse style using intellij - intellij only loads the style into java editor, it does not seem to use it in the scala editor...let me know if you have any advice on getting this done with intellij?

@rabbah, for now I'll hardcode activation limit into the CLI for the usage information. I have another PR open for making the max activation limit configurable with Ansible and displaying the value through the controller info route. After that change is finished, we can update the CLI to read the limits dynamically from the controller and remove the hardcoded values.
@bjustin-ibm I think this is ready now take a look

```
The Node.js project will be releasing new versions across all of its active release lines (4.x, 6.x, 8.x) as well as 7.x the week of July 10th 2017 to incorporate a security fix.
```

3. leave npm packages alone and just update nodejs

PG4 477 - Passed

@rabbah, recent a change went in that flipped the update flag to `true` for action updates (https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/commit/9c1f77fdb1e4a7339634434dc90c45026d6a43d2#diff-41c5935cb68718d73fa6ef611c927cc4R100). This enabled the ability to get action annotations that already exist and append new annotations to that list when updating a web action. However, preserving annotations that already exist is not a feature that is synced across commands (package update, trigger update, etc...). As per a conversation with @mdeuser, we are thinking about flipping the update flag back to `flase` so that the same update functionality is used across commands.
@Katiyman, as a work-around, try prepending `http://` to the apihost when you set it. Ex: `./wsk property set --apihost http://10.xxx.11.xx:5009`

To capture some of the offline discussion with @mdeuser 

User Agents value needs to follow spec
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2616#section-3.8

```
  product         = token ["/" product-version]
       product-version = token

   Examples:

       User-Agent: CERN-LineMode/2.15 libwww/2.17b3
       Server: Apache/0.8.4
```
One idea is to have something like this that identifies that the request is coming from the web action, also passing some type of product-version
```
"User Agent": "OpenWhisk-Routemgt/4567"
```
```
WSK_BUILD_NUMBER = wsk property get | grep "API build number"
```
```
wsk package update routemgt --param __ow_version $WSK_BUILD_NUMBER
```
The web action could also append any incoming Agent-Header value to the final Agent-Header sent to the API GW
@markusthoemmes I think formatting is proper now - let me know if you have other feedback?

@mdeuser, @rabbah, the alternative here would be to always pass in a value of `false` into this line: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/tools/cli/go-whisk-cli/commands/action.go#L402. Eventually we can allow all the update commands to preserve all annotations/parameters and add a special flag to delete annotations/parameters as well.
closing this one as we are going to work on creating images and kinds for builder/init actions, and keep the the images for invocations small
Also I think you need to rebase/merge to upstream/master

I have not succeeded in using docker for mac yet.
First issue was getting ansible to locate `docker-py` correctly. The best solution was setting PYTHONPATH in my enviornment (although likely this should be in an env file for ansible)

```
> export PYTHONPATH=/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages
```

after that, i'm running into deployment issues:
```
TASK [prereq : install requests] *************************************************************************************************************************
Saturday 01 July 2017  10:30:18 -0400 (0:00:00.022)       0:00:01.305 ********* 
fatal: [172.17.0.1]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "failed": true, "module_stderr": "sudo: a password is required\n", "module_stdout": "", "msg": "MODULE FAILURE", "rc": 1}
```

i bypassed that since I already installed the prereqs.

got through deploying couchdb, and building - failed in deploying consul:

```
TASK [consul : remove consul config directory] ***********************************************************************************************************
Saturday 01 July 2017  11:10:19 -0400 (0:00:00.245)       0:00:01.825 ********* 
fatal: [172.17.0.1]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "failed": true, "module_stderr": "sudo: a password is required\n", "module_stdout": "", "msg": "MODULE FAILURE", "rc": 1}
```
one issue found is that our configuration of the db run on "localhost" but the deployment of the containers is on the remote host which means the precomputed `db_prefix` will not match.
@ddragosd I didn't squash my last two commits in case they're helpful to you. I'm happy to abandon this pr as noted I'm trying to get on docker for mac and didn't want to deal with consul.
Nuked consul (see #2452) now it appears log dirs cannot be created without sudo :/

done for now - the invoker deployment is messy: all the shell commands failed for me.
and for some reason the logs directory frequently ends up owned by root and requires a sudo intervention.
You're making it easier with this PR @rabbah 😄  ; we can merge this one instead, and drop #2277. I'll try it as soon as I get a chance.
Rebased.

a) are there individual client certificates we need to deal with, or is it just the auto-generated one?
 **answer: in openwhisk codes, we don't need to deal with individual client certificates, it is best to generated by the company who use openwhisk to deploy their serverless env for all users. The client certificate can be signed by their self-signed root certificate or trusted CA organization sigend root certificate.**
    a.1) if there are individual (per user) client certificates how does those get generated so that it is valid with the OW server certificate?
 **answer: server certificate has no relation with client certificate, their root certifiate can be different or same, also worked well. the per user client certificate is generated by their self-signed root certificate or trusted CA organization sigend root certificate.(above also refered)**
    a.2) if there are individual (per user) client certificates does they contain any namespace related information that can be used upstream, i.e. openwhisk controller, to authorize the request?
 **answer: for our case, the client certificate subj includes CN=${emploeeid}, and other fields such as C, ST, L, O may be the depend on company's organization**


b) what exact security issue does this solve? does it protect for man-in-the-middle attacks only, or have you other ideas in mind to use that mechanism?
   **answer: this feature just increase the security for auth, but it is optional default, if  set ${nginx.ssl.verify_client} values to on, wsk client must pass client certificate, not every user can use wsk tool to send request to openwhisk server, if want to do that, must get their own client certificate from comany.  Other guess, we may simplify the auth flow, if pass client certificate, in controlller, we can igore the auth key verify.(but i don't sure it has possible to simplify the auth flow)**


c) is the usage of the client certificate mandatory?  
**answer: no, it is optional, default configuration for {ssl.nginx.verify_client} value is optional, so user can pass client certificate or not, also worked well, if set  {ssl.nginx.verify_client} value to on, so user must
pass client certifciate.**

d) I saw that you’re generating the server and client certificate during `setup.yml`. what would be the steps to generate the corresponding per user client certificate?
**answer: openwhisk has no need to care how to generate the client certificate, it just provide the configuration entry point  how to use it. setup.yml's genssh.sh just  a example provides steps how to generate client certificate.**

e) how does it work if I don’t have a hostname and only an IP. I’ve tried it with my `docker-machine` environment and get `x509: cannot validate certificate for 192.168.99.101 because it doesn't contain any IP SANs`
**answer: i should verity it.**

I think this feature is worth in the aspect of providing different authentication method.
X509 client certificate is very common way to authenticate client(user).
Many cloud provider such as AWS also support it.

If OW supports this feature, user can just issue certificate for him and set it up for subsequent activities.
In certificate, there will be information about users(subject).
Since certificate is validated by root(trusted) CA, once it is validated, no more authentication process is required in server side.

This can coexists with current auth method(`--auth`), and no need other extra component(such as db), it would be great to have this optional feature.

But surely, corresponding server side changes are also required.
@dubeej thanks James .. will do and let you know...

@ningyougang @style95 many thanks for clarifying and answering my questions above. that helps to better understand. It would be great if you could verify on e) because this might be a typical case in local or test environments and we should avoid that test cases are failing (like in openstack, kubernetes, docker-machine, ... environments)
@csantanapr all good now 🚀

This is an exciting development.

Do you think it could be possible to support dynamic composer dependencies? 
Perhaps something like http://melody.sensiolabs.org/

My current view is that you should provide a zip file with your vendor folder in it as it's too slow to fetch dependencies dynamically. This is how it works for NodeJS actions. 

Regards,

I see you updated validateParameter.sh in the openwhisk-catalog based on my previous comment.  However, you will also need to update the install script (installCatalog.sh) file in the pushnotification repo (https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-package-pushnotifications) to remove the namespace parameter before this update can go in.  The updates to all three of these repos really needed to go in at the same time to avoid breaks.  Right now the catalog install from openwhisk-catalog is broken due to https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-catalog/pull/231 getting in and this PR not being in yet.

@DanLavine, @daisy-ycguo  - please fix this situation (see comment above).  You need to update https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-package-pushnotifications/blob/master/packages/installCatalog.sh to remove the namespace parameter if you are removing it from here just as you already did for the openwhisk-catalog repo.  All three of these needed to go in together.

The controller logs suggest that consul is not reachable from the controller container. Are you using an IP address that is reachable from inside docker? Notice 10. vs 172.

@jasonpet I don't see what is blocking this PR from being merged as it fixes the install catalog script appropriately. 

I had no idea that the other repo also relied on the incubator-openwhisk-catalog repo dependency as I was able to standup OpenWhisk with just these 2 PRs. I can fix it as well.

@dubeejw - would you please review.

My fault, I misunderstood the bug meaning. Yes, correct, the best solution perhaps would be a more flexible container/warmup memory strategy. For example, I can think of some user could pay a premium openwhisk service, so their actions could consume more than 512m limit size. But maybe we could set the jvm heap Xmx a little less than 512m as a temp workaround.
I think both LICENSE and LICENSE.txt are fine. I see some projects use LICESE.txt and some projects use LICENSE.

Can you clarify further what you're trying to do?

In general actions cannot receive incoming connections - so running an action as a server is not in scope.

The reason there's a server proxy inside an action is for internal communication with the control system.
Thanks for the correction. Do you have an ICLA on file?
